title: Information for Prospective Students
subtitle: PhD, Master's, and Bachelor's Thesis Opportunities

phd_students.title: PhD Opportunities
phd_students.introduction: I am interested in supervising PhD students working at the intersection of logic, artificial intelligence, and formal reasoning. If you are passionate about foundational questions in AI and enjoy both theoretical and practical work, I encourage you to get in touch.

topics.description: Developing formal frameworks for reasoning about uncertainty, knowledge, and belief in multi-agent systems
Combining temporal reasoning with probabilistic models for dynamic environments
Using Answer Set Programming (ASP) and Inductive Logic Programming (ILASP) for real-world problems
Creating interpretable AI systems using formal logic and argumentation theory
Learning argumentation semantics and developing computational models of argument
Reasoning about actions, their effects, and knowledge-producing operations

supervision_approach.title: My Supervision Philosophy
paragraphs: I emphasize hands-on research with strong theoretical foundations. My approach combines rigorous formal methods with practical implementation, typically leading to both publications and open-source contributions.
Students I supervise are encouraged to present their work at conferences, collaborate with international researchers, and engage with the broader AI and logic communities.
I believe in regular meetings, clear milestones, and maintaining a balance between independent exploration and structured guidance.

current_openings.message: I am currently open to discussing potential PhD supervision opportunities at the University of Salento, University of Verona, and University College London.
notes: Funding availability varies by institution and program
Competitive scholarships are available for excellent candidates
I can assist with scholarship applications and institutional procedures

application_process.title: How to Apply

steps.details: Familiarize yourself with my research areas and recent publications to ensure alignment with your interests
Draft a 2-3 page outline describing your research interests, potential research questions, and how they relate to my work
Send your CV, transcript, research proposal, and a brief cover letter to fabioaurelio.dasaro@unisalento.it
After initial discussion, apply through the official PhD program at the relevant institution

requirements: Strong background in logic, computer science, mathematics, or philosophy
Experience with formal methods or programming (Python, ASP, Prolog, or similar)
Curiosity, independence, and strong problem-solving skills

masters_students.title: Master's Thesis (Laurea Magistrale)
masters_students.introduction: On this page you will find information for students at the University of Verona interested in writing a Master's thesis under my supervision.

how_to_proceed.title: How to Proceed
how_to_proceed.text: I invite you to first review my publications and research interests (summarized below among the proposed topics), and then express your interest by sending me an email.

prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
prerequisites.general: My research methodologies belong primarily to formal logic and computer science, but each of these topics has implications for ethical and epistemological problems that can also be explored in a Philosophy thesis.
prerequisites.requirements: Master's students (laurea magistrale) will be required to have greater competencies and prerequisites, which will vary depending on the topic and the candidate's background.

topics.title: The Logical Omniscience Problem
topics.description: The logical omniscience problem in epistemic logic and propositional attitudes.
topics.references: For an introduction, see the Wikipedia page on propositional attitudes, the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy page on epistemic logics, particularly section 4.

topics.title: Bounded Rationality and Depth-Bounded Logics
topics.description: Bounded rationality and depth-bounded logics.
topics.references: See for example the articles 'The Enduring Scandal of Deduction' by M. D'Agostino and L. Floridi, 'An informational view of classical logic' by M. D'Agostino, the k-lingo system and associated publication.

topics.title: Analysis of Turing's Writings
topics.description: Historical, conceptual, and philological analysis of Alan Turing's writings, with particular emphasis on interpreting certain (more or less) controversial passages.
topics.references: Such as the formal analysis of the Church-Turing Thesis (is it physically plausible?).

topics.title: Bias and Fairness in Machine Learning
topics.description: Conceptual and experimental analysis of bias and fairness in modern Machine Learning systems.
topics.references: ChatGPT, Stable Diffusion, etc.

topics.title: Knowledge Representation and Common-Sense Reasoning
topics.description: Knowledge representation and common-sense reasoning logics, especially Event Calculus.
topics.references: See a web interface under development.

topics.title: Inductive Logic Programming Applications
topics.description: Applications of Inductive Logic Programming.
topics.references: See the ILASP system and a video of its application.

topics.title: Explainable AI for Machine Learning
topics.description: Explainable AI for Machine Learning systems, especially the use of ILASP and FASTLAS to explain the output of Deep Learning systems, and the connections between Reinforcement Learning and Probabilistic Event Calculus.
topics.references: Here a publication on this topic.

topics.title: Formal Argumentation
topics.description: Formal argumentation, especially their interaction with temporal logics.
topics.references: See, for example, the Wikipedia page on argumentation frameworks.

topics.title: The Problem of Time in Logic
topics.description: The problem of time in logic: the frame problem, qualification problem, ramification problem and their extensions.
topics.references: See Wikipedia and an article by Daniel Dennett for a quick introduction, and extensions in the field of affordances and in ethics.

topics.title: Fairness Measures
topics.description: Fairness measures.
topics.references: See for example TPTND and themes from the BRIO project.

latex_guidance.title: Typography and LaTeX
latex_guidance.preference: Theses can be written in Word, but I generally prefer that theses be written in LaTeX, especially if you choose to work on topics related to Logic.
latex_guidance.about_latex: LaTeX is software widely used in academia for writing articles, books, and presentations. Learning to use it is simpler than it may seem at first glance, especially since the online collaborative version Overleaf is available, which requires no installation on your computer.
latex_guidance.support: Moreover, I'm always here to help! The result, I assure you, will be much more aesthetically pleasing and will give you numerous long-term advantages.

contact.note: Please send me an email expressing your interest, along with your academic background and which research topic interests you most.

faqs.question: Do I need to know Italian?
faqs.answer: No. While research in Italy, all my supervision and research work is conducted in English. However, learning Italian can enhance your experience.

faqs.question: Can I work remotely?
faqs.answer: PhD programs typically require physical presence, but flexible arrangements may be possible for part of the time, depending on the institution and project.

faqs.question: What is the typical duration?
faqs.answer: PhD programs in Italy are typically 3 years, while UK programs are usually 3-4 years. Bachelor's and Master's theses typically take 6-12 months depending on the project scope.

faqs.question: What is the difference between Laurea Triennale and Laurea Magistrale?
faqs.answer: Laurea triennale is a 3-year bachelor's degree, while laurea magistrale is a 2-year master's degree. Both require a thesis for completion. Master's students are expected to have more advanced competencies and deeper engagement with research.

faqs.question: Can I propose my own thesis topic?
faqs.answer: Yes! While I've listed several research areas, I'm open to discussing topics that combine your interests with my research expertise. Contact me to explore possibilities.

faqs.question: Do I need programming experience?
faqs.answer: For bachelor's theses, prior programming experience is not required if you show willingness to learn. For master's and PhD work, some technical background is beneficial, though the specific requirements vary by topic.
